subject: Re: [junit] Paper on Abstract vs. Concrete parameters

Yes, that rings true with me, and looks like a good analysis.  Thanks
for w=
riting that up!

Seems to me that the "third way" here is the one I gravita=
te towards:
pass the narrowest possible interface into the method in questi=
on.  In
each case, you could define an interface with two getters and pass
=
that into the method.  Your production code would have "Customer
implements=
 MortalityCriteria" for the first scenario.  For the second
case, you could=
 have the "legacy" method cobble together a dynamic
implementation, or the =
class could contain a private implementation
that it constructs only once t=
o call the new method.  The worst
penalty you pay is having big classes lik=
e Customer bogged down with a
ton of interfaces, but in my practice that do=
esn't seem to happen too
often.

FYI, I thought your initial message about =
the idea was clear too, so I
may not be your target audience.  ;)

On Wed, =
Aug 27, 2008 at 3:38 PM, kentb <kentb@...> wrote:
> All,
>
> In s=
pite of the one feedback message I got that my recent post about
> abstract=
 vs. concrete parameters was clear, I expanded the idea into a
> paper: www=
.threeriversinstitute.org/AbstractVsConcreteParameters.html. In
> short, it=
 tries to resolve the apparent contradiction between achieving
> testable c=
ode sometimes by making parameters concrete and sometimes by
> making param=
eters abstract. I'd appreciate feedback, examples, and
> counter-examples.
=
>
> Regards,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
